Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Experimental Seawater Laboratory at the Coastal Studies Center, Bowdoin College
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Bowdoin College Coastal Studies Center (http://www.bowdoin.edu/coastal-studies-center/) is awarded a grant to expand the capabilities of an existing flowing seawater system so that climate variables can be independently manipulated in experimental aquaria. The Coastal Studies Center (CSC) on Orr's Island in mid-Coast Maine, is an educational and research laboratory serving Bowdoin College and visiting students and researchers. The CSC has a sentinel position at the southern boundary of the Gulf of Maine, a cold-water boundary that is moving northward as the Earth's climate warms. Further, the once highly productive Gulf of Maine faces other synergistic impacts including overfishing and invasive species that are changing the structure and function of kelp forests, the rocky intertidal, seagrass beds, and salt marshes. While several research-focused marine laboratories rim the Gulf of Maine, the CSC is a unique RUI focused center that is focused on facilitating undergraduate engagement on the problems of a rapidly changing ocean. This project improves the RUI capabilities of Bowdoin College, which has significantly increased female and minority enrollment over the last ten years. The new experimental seawater capabilities are also likely to attract new visiting students and faculty, expanding the CSC research community. Finally, the improvements will allow increased experimentation and monitoring of estuarine systems. Estuaries support high biological productivity, yet they also experience stronger and more variable impacts of ocean acidity than the open ocean due to the reduced buffering capacity of freshwater inputs and high biological contributions of carbon dioxide. A new cluster of sensors will sample key climate change variables (including crucial pCO2) in Harpswell Sound and stream this data to Internet portals year round, providing a much-needed estuarine node in the Gulf of Maine.

The project has two major elements: 1. building four experimental seawater modules that will independently control temperature, oxygen levels, pH, and sterilize effluent; and 2. constructing a pier-mounted instrument array to continuously monitor climatic variables. Element 1 includes a seawater cooling system that combines an external centralized chilling unit with four independent chilled water loops (modules) that can cool 400 gallons of seawater from summer ambient temperatures to 4 degrees Celsius. Additionally, each module will be fitted with the plumbing, controls, and sensors to manipulate dissolved oxygen levels and pH via addition of nitrogen and carbon dioxide gasses respectively. An inline UV filter system will be added for experimental applications that culture non-native organisms and require effluent sterilization. Element 2 will install a pier-based environmental monitoring platform, that will stream temperature, salinity, pH, and pCO2 data to a global research community 365 days a year. This new monitoring location in Harpswell Sound will provide key environmental data on how estuarine marine systems are responding to climate change, and provide essential data for parameterizing climate change experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit - Located at Bowdoin College?s Schiller Coastal Studies Center (formerly the Coastal Studies Center) on the coast of southern Maine, the project constructed a seawater climate control system and a pier-mounted instrument array to autonomously measure and log seawater chemistry and biological variables. The seawater climate control system allows independent manipulation of temperature, ocean acidity (pH), and the concentration of dissolved oxygen; in a variety of running seawater aquarium formats and sizes.  Simultaneously, the pier-mounted instrument array measures: temperature, salinity, pH, dissolved oxygen concentration, partial carbon dioxide concentration, chlorophyll concentrations, and sediment concentration.  All measurements are recorded and logged by computer, with over 50 sampling intervals per day. These improvements will facilitate intra- and extramural teaching and research programs that seek to predict the impacts of climate change on seawater chemistry and the biological systems that live in the Gulf of Maine ecosystem. The Gulf of Maine is a historically cold and economically productive ecosystem, whose fisheries are changing rapidly due to a warming climate. Relevant programs include biology, oceanography, fisheries science, and environmental policy, and thus the improvements are likely to stimulate inter-disciplinary approaches to solving environmental challenges. The infrastructure provides new capabilities to use local environmental data to improve the design of experiments that seek to determine the impacts of climate change, because control baselines can be accurately based on current values of water temperature, ocean acidity, and dissolved oxygen.  This is a unique and innovative capability when considering other marine laboratories located in coastal Maine or the greater New England region.

Broader Impacts - There are four major broader impacts of this project.  First, all data from the pier-mounted instrumental array are available via the Internet for the science community and general public.  These data compliment similar data sets from offshore buoys and coastal marine laboratories, creating a network of environmental monitoring in the Gulf of Maine region.  Second, the seawater climate control system is available to the extramural community and this project helped stimulate a large private donation for the site, which is building new housing for visiting researchers and a new dry laboratory facility. This new infrastructure is likely to greatly expand the use and extra-mural reach of the Schiller Coastal Studies Center. Third, this project complements a growing aquaculture industry based on shellfish in coastal Maine. In the Casco Bay region near Portland, ME, there is an increased need for environmental data sets that can measure the impacts of ocean acidification by local growers. This project provides that data freely to this community. Lastly, the project is aiding in training the next generation of environmental scientists and policy makers by providing advanced research tools to the undergraduate community at Bowdoin College. These new tools are being incorporated into existing courses in the biological and physical sciences, as well as independent research projects, and are the basis for planning future curricula based on inquiry-based teaching.
